sections.summary: Authority over **spoils** is assigned to Allah and His Messenger, while the characteristics of true believers are defined through their **faith**, reliance on their Lord, and maintenance of **prayer**.

Historical reluctance among some believers is contrasted with Allah’s plan to confirm the truth via reinforcement with **angels** and natural elements like rain. The text commands striking the necks of those who oppose the divine **decree**. [131–132]
Believers are forbidden from fleeing the field except for tactical maneuvering, and military victory is explicitly attributed to **divine agency** rather than human prowess.

Directives to obey Allah and the Messenger emphasize that **possessions** and **children** serve as a **test** of faith. Sincere consciousness of Allah grants the believer a **criterion** for discernment. [132–133]

Despite disbelieving schemes and expenditures to repel people from the path, Allah is the supreme planner. It identifies the **pious** as the only rightful custodians of the Sacred Mosque and commands fighting until **persecution** is ended.

Rulings establish a one-fifth share of **spoils** for the Messenger and the needy, referencing the Battle of Badr as the **Day of Distinction**. Divine intervention in human perception is highlighted to facilitate a **predetermined matter**. [134–135]
Believers are instructed to remain firm and avoid boastfulness, while the spiritual consequences of disbelief are illustrated through the striking of disbelievers by **angels** at death.

The text rebukes those who violate **covenants** and mandates military preparation to terrify enemies. It permits inclining toward **peace** if the enemy does so, crediting Allah with the **unity of hearts**. [135–136]

Encouragement to rouse the believers includes victory ratios adjusted for **patience** and strength. Rules for **prisoners** prioritize the pursuit of the **Hereafter** over worldly merchandise. [136–137]

Bonds are established between the **Emigrants** and **Supporters** as spiritual allies. The surah concludes by noting that **family members** are nearer to one another in the Book of Allah regarding social obligations. [137–138]
